title: Uber, China rival in funding drive
content:
Uber Technologies and its Chinese rival Didi Kuaidi were both closing in on the latest round in fundraising drives to fuel their battle for China’s ride-hailing market. Uber chief executive Travis Kalanick told Chinese news website Sina that it had raised $US1.2 billion ($1.7bn) so far from investors for its China unit, including an additional investment from strategic partner Baidu.

An Uber spokeswoman confirmed the comments but declined to say how much Baidu invested in this round. A Baidu spokesman also confirmed the investment, declining to give a sum.

Didi Kuaidi is approaching a “second closing” that would raise an additional $US1bn, after bringing in $US2bn in July, two sources said. The combined $US3bn fundraising round could be the largest ever by a tech start-up.

The Wall Street Journal previously reported that Uber China was closing in on a $US1bn funding round that would value the Chinese business at about $US7.5bn, and that Didi Kuaidi was raising further funding that could reach $US1bn.

Baidu first invested in Uber at the end of December and has not disclosed the size of its investment.
